title: lifetime "parameter 'a is never used" even though it is
body:
If a default type parameter requires a lifetime argument, but the actual structure does not, we will get the "parameter 'a is never used" message.

The issue can be reproduced with the following code.

``` Rust
struct Foo<'a> {
    a: &'a str,
}

struct Bar<'a, T = Foo<'a>> {
    b: T,
}
```

Causing the compiler error:

```
tests/lang.rs:970:16: 970:18 error: parameter `'a` is never used
tests/lang.rs:970     struct Bar<'a, T = Foo<'a>> {
                                 ^~
tests/lang.rs:970:16: 970:18 help: consider removing `'a` or using a marker such as `core::marker::PhantomData`
tests/lang.rs:970     struct Bar<'a, T = Foo<'a>> {
```

It can be made to work as follows ...

``` Rust
use std::marker::PhantomData;
struct BarWorking <'a, T = Foo<'a>> 
    where T: 'a {
    b: T,
    _m: &'a PhantomData<T>,
}
```

... yet I think if 'a is used in a Default type, it should not be thought of as unused. In my example, it is quite hard to instantiate such a structure as it uses borrowed phantom data. If `&'a` is removed, the compiler error will be back as well, so `where T: 'a` does still not qualify as usage of `'a`.

Maybe this is expected, yet I felt the need to make sure. Thanks for your understanding.
